Āryamahāmegha

div.head: Summary
div.p: This brief discourse describes a visit from the Buddha Śākyamuni to the realm of the nāgas. After the assembly of nāgas pays homage to the Buddha with a grand array of magically emanated offerings, their king asks the Buddha to explain how the nāgas can eliminate their own suffering and aid sentient beings by causing rain to fall and crops to grow. The Buddha, in response, extols the benefits of loving-kindness and then teaches them a dhāraṇī that when accompanied by the recitation of a host of buddha names will pacify the nāgas’ suffering and cause crops to grow. The nāga king then asks for an incantation that will cause rain to fall during times of drought. The Buddha grants this request, teaching the assembly a longer incantation to be recited for the purpose of bringing rainfall. The discourse concludes with instructions for constructing an altar and holding a ritual rainmaking service.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This translation was produced by Joshua Capitanio for the Mahamegha translation team.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.
[Sponsored by XXXXXX]

This text is a short dhāraṇī-sūtra that may be regarded as an addendum to the longer Great Cloud Discourse (Toh 232) Mahamegha Translation Group, trans., The Great Cloud Discourse (Mahāmeghasūtra), Toh 232 (84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha, 2022). and seems to have been intended for ritual and recitation purposes. The longer discourse is a Mahāyāna scripture that emphasizes bodhisattva conduct and the teaching that the Buddha does not pass into parinirvāṇa. Among the many benefits listed for those who uphold The Great Cloud Discourse, timely rainfall is mentioned, and thus The Great Cloud Discourse came to be associated with rainmaking among Indian Buddhists. This short text, which circulated independently of the longer Great Cloud Discourse, is presented as the “sixty-fourth chapter” of that Great Cloud Discourse, which in all its extant versions contains only thirty-eight chapters.

The dhāraṇī-sūtra centers on an assembly of nāga kings who vow to support the Buddhist teachings and assist sentient beings by providing timely rain. Their leader asks the Buddha for a method that will pacify all the nāgas so that they will be able to cause rain to fall and thereby nourish sentient beings. The Buddha then presents several dhāraṇīs and lists of buddha names that, when recited, should bring about their specified results. The text concludes with a short instruction on a ritual procedure to be performed when reciting these incantations for the purpose of bringing rainfall.

The text appears to have circulated widely and enjoyed considerable popularity, as evidenced by the fact that it was translated into Chinese four different times between the sixth and eighth centuries. Two Tibetan translations of this text exist. Toh 234 is a shorter version entitled The Chapter on the Great Cloud Maṇḍala of Wind, the Essence of All Nāgas (Āryamahāmeghavāyumaṇḍalaparivartasarvanāgahṛdaya). The slightly longer text translated here (Toh 235) is simply titled The Noble Great Cloud, but in the colophon the title is similarly given as The Maṇḍala of Wind That Sends Down Rainfall. This text is also included in the Tantra and Dharani sections of the Degé Kangyur, where it appears as Toh 657 and Toh 1063, respectively. The text is included in the Tibetan Kangyur collections of different periods and is also recorded in the Denkarma ldan dkar ma, folio 299.a. See also Herrmann-Pfandt 2008, pp. 193–94. catalog of Tibetan imperial translations (but not in the Phangthangma catalog). Thus, it appears that it was first translated from Sanskrit into Tibetan no later than the early ninth century, as the Denkarma is dated to 812 ce. Five versions of this text are also found among the manuscripts recovered from the caves of Dunhuang. These are noted in Herrmann-Pfandt 2008, p. 193. In addition to these Tibetan translations, a partial Sanskrit version is also extant. Bendall 1880, Moriguchi 1980. The English translation presented here was based primarily on the Tibetan Degé edition, in consultation with the Comparative Edition (dpe bsdur ma) and the Stok Palace manuscript edition.

div.head: Great Cloud
div.p: Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Bhagavān was at the home of the nāga kings Joyous and Overjoyed, a great multistoried maṇḍala palace of clouds having the essence of precious and auspicious jewels, together with a great assembly of bhikṣus, a great assembly of bodhisattvas, and a great host of nāga kings.

There were the nāga kings Joyous, Overjoyed, Ocean, Never Hot, Magnificent, Water God, Cutter, Guardian of the Area, Son of Vast Wealth, Upholds Charity, Son of Earth Guardian, Spotted, Glorious Splendor, Noble Glory, Lightning Garland, Precious Jewel Crest, Aloft Jewel Crest, Brilliant Topknot, and Rainbow Topknot. There were also nāga kings Indra’s Standard, Indra’s Offering, Victory Banner of Jambudvīpa, Auspicious, Great Maṇḍala, Great Crawler, Star Color, Moon’s Brilliance, Noble Mind, and Sees the Moon, and there were the nāga kings Well Seeing, Extremely Stable, Jeweled Neck, Arising Cloud, Showering Rain, Utterly Victorious, Completely Victorious, Powerful Roar, Great Hood, and Deep Voice. There were also the nāga kings Sounding Rain, Completely Sounding, Utpala, Great Energy, Plough Holder, Variegated, and Great Lasso, the nāga king Cardamom Leaf, All Illuminating, Rough Ears, Conch, Daradara, This is a phonetic rendering of the Tibetan da ra da ra. the nāga king Upadaradara, This is a phonetic rendering of the Tibetan u pa da ra da ra. Pleasant, Slitherer, Great Slitherer, Great Scent, Soarer, No Straw, Hanger, Cocoon, and Black. There were also the nāga kings Indra’s Army, Reed, Lesser Reed, Wafting Smoke, Floater, Beautified, Great Elephant’s Trunk, Sharp, Light Yellow, Lightning Blaze, Great Lightning Flash, Powerful God, and Water Power. There were also the nāga kings Concealed Purity, Nectar, Forder, Beryl Light, Golden Voice, Golden Light, Lunar Crest’s Brilliance, Sunlight, Dawn, and Elephant Head. There were also the nāga kings White, Black, Lord of Death, Virtuous, Toad, Faith’s Splendor, Rim Holder, Earth Holder, Thousand Heads, and Jewel Crest. There were also the nāga kings Significant Vision, Great Cloud, Fine Army, Earth Protector, Man’s Gift, Completely Tamed, Decay Arising, Crocodile, Crocodile Face, and Poisonous. There were also the nāga kings Swift Poison, Padmaka, Entrance, Utterly Soaring, Terrible One, Brilliantly Beautified, Five Heads, Balira, and Victorious Chariot. There were also the nāga kings Unsurpassed, Long Tail, Great Head, Bimbīka, Vitara, and Quick, the nāga kings Three Heads, Nāga Army, Great Splendor, and Reed Giver, and the nāga kings Terrifying, Blazing Light, Seven Heads, Universe, Joy to Behold, Utterly Wrathful, Stainless Splendor, Fine Eyes, Great Fury, and Mass of Light Rays. There were also the nāga kings Fierce, Wrathful Manner, Precious Water Offering, Water-Bearing Great Cloud, Indra’s Light, Tree, Cloud Moon, Oceanic Cloud, Great Flower Scent, and Kumuda Source. There were also the nāga kings Precious Eyes, Great Crested Banner, Great Cloud Essence, Snowy, Noble Essence, Powerful Cloud, Night Holder, Water Offering, and Great Water Offering and the nāga kings No Splendor, King of Cloud Lords, Wrathless, Earth Vase, Nāga Glory, Water Holder, Cloud Parasol, Aṅgira Face, Splendid, and Perfectly Cloud Born. There were also the nāga kings Limitless Gait, Water Beautifier, Great Body, Food Eater, Peaceful, Courageous, Black Gold, Supreme Effort, Pure Poison, and Fine Sound. There were also the nāga kings Nectar Essence, Great Shower, Completely Quaking, Chaotic Sound, Drumbeat, Flowing Nectar, Cheerer, Roar, Noble Army, Child without Craving, and Oceanic Lightning, and there was the nāga king Deceiver.

Encompassing these nāga kings and all the rest, there were altogether eighty-four septillion nāgas gathered there. Arranging their seats, they all sat down together. At this point, all those nāga kings, together with their retinues, arose from their seats, draped their robes over one shoulder, knelt with their right knees on the ground, joined their palms, and saluted the Bhagavān. With devotion to him as their guru and with great respect, they made unfathomable, immeasurable offerings to the Bhagavān of flowers, incense, perfumes, garlands, ointments, powders, clothes, parasols, victory banners, banners, silk tassels, music, cymbals, minstrels, songs, jeweled flowers, jeweled tassels, pearl garlands, nāga flowers, and supremely beautiful pearl-adorned nets. They then circumambulated the Bhagavān and sat down together.

Once they were all seated, they made a vow together: “With oceans of bodies as numerous as all the atomic particles in all the oceanic world-systems, we make offerings The phrase “we make offerings” is added for clarification. to all oceanic maṇḍalas of buddhas and bodhisattvas with their retinues. Within each and every atomic particle of earth, water, fire, and wind and all the atomic particles of apparent forms within all the infinite oceanic world-systems lies an oceanic cloud of bodies that are beyond countless, unfathomable, inconceivable, unparalleled, immeasurable, inexpressible, and more numerous than all numerable oceans. Upon each and every one of these bodies are emanated immeasurable, countless oceanic clouds of hands, from which are emanated oceanic clouds of all manner of offerings, distinct and radiating continuously in all directions. With these, we will make offerings to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.”

Thinking thus, they continued: “We will fill the sky with unfathomable, countless, inconceivable, immeasurable, incalculable, inexpressible, distinct emanations of bodies engaging in the perfect conduct of Samantabhadra, with oceanic clouds of bodhisattva bodies, and likewise with oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of all manner of jewels, densely arrayed rays of light, and bodies of all suns and moons, together with oceanic clouds of jeweled garlands and flowers; oceanic clouds of great mansions made from the essence of all brilliant jewels; oceanic clouds of storehouses of all manner of powders and trees; oceanic clouds of incenses, perfumes, and all manner of apparent forms; oceanic clouds of the sounds of instruments resounding with all manner of music; and oceanic clouds of all manner of trees used for incense. We will fill the sky with these emanations, with an oceanic cloud of all manner of offerings that are unfathomable, countless, inconceivable, immeasurable, incalculable, inexpressible, and distinct. Having done all this, we will proceed to pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of kings of jewels within which all the arrayed realms of existence are illuminated. Having done so, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of arrayed kings of jewels that shower down a rain of all-illuminating gemstones; oceanic clouds of kings of jewels blazing with the light of all gemstones, resounding with the melodic sounds of the attainment of buddhahood; oceanic clouds of kings of jewels filling everywhere with the universal resounding of the melodies of all the Dharma teachings of the buddhas; oceanic clouds of emanated buddha bodies illuminated by jeweled light radiating from all directions; oceanic clouds of kings of jewels that display the appearance of all the arrayed, distinct maṇḍalas; oceanic clouds of kings of jewels whose brilliant lamp-like rays of light enter into all buddha realms; oceanic clouds of kings of jewels that display the appearances of all the immeasurable palaces of the tathāgatas in all the inconceivable buddhafields; and an oceanic cloud of kings of jewels that illuminate the display of the bodies of the buddhas of the three times within the atomic particles of all variety of gemstones. With these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of distinct multistoried palaces of sundry jewels, incense, and flowers; oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces completely adorned with kings of jewels of an infinite variety of colors; oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces with jeweled lamps and radiant incense; oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces thoroughly bedecked with all manner of pearls; oceanic clouds of the anthers of all manner of flowers; and oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces beautifully adorned with infinite jewel garlands. We will then fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces that completely contain an adornment of all essences whose brilliance illuminates the ten directions; oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces that appear completely ornamented everywhere with adornments of fine particles of all manner of jewels; oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces filled to overflowing with adornments of all manner of decorations; and oceanic clouds of multistoried palaces with flowered arches at each doorway hung with lattices of bells. With these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing necklaces of gold and various jewels and jeweled chokers; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing various brilliant flowers; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing various lotus flowers with the blue The word “blue” is added for clarification. color of the indranīla jewel and the golden hue of the Jambu River; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing precious jeweled lotus lamps; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing brilliantly bejeweled lotus victory banners; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing various lotus flowers adorned with jewels; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing lotus flowers decorated with indranīla jewels and blazing with golden light; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing lotus flowers endowed with inexhaustibly brilliant blazing light; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing lotus flowers that produce all manner of blazing jewels; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing lotus flowers that produce all manner of supremely sublime blazing jewels; and distinct oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing lotus flowers endowed with the light rays of the sound of the Buddha’s speech. With these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of trees festooned with all manner of gemstones; oceanic clouds of incense trees wreathed all over with leaves that emanate clouds of joined palms; oceanic clouds of trees that appear as an infinite array of all forms of trees; oceanic clouds of trees draped with clouds of all manner of flowers; oceanic clouds of trees endowed with infinite troves that produce all manner of adornments; oceanic clouds of trees completely illuminated by maṇḍalas of light radiated from all manner of jewels; oceanic clouds of trees that manifest busts of bodhisattva bodies made from all manner of sandalwood powders; oceanic clouds of trees endowed with the brilliant solar light of the storehouse of all manner of precious clothing of the infinite tree spirits adorning all seats of awakening with inconceivable brilliant light; and oceanic clouds of trees emitting pleasing tones that resound with all manner of melodies.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of “We will fill the sky with emanations of” has been added here and below. oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing infinite jewel-colored lotus flowers; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing the brilliant, multifaceted kings of jewels; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing adornments of all manner of ornamentation; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing garlands of lamps that radiate the brilliant light of various jewels; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing the source of a universally resounding rainfall of jewels; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing precious garlands of all manner of incense, flowers, and lotus flowers; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing the kings of jewels that completely manifest the adornments of the seats of all buddhas; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing clouds of jewels and completely adorned with railed arches draped with garlands of all manner of adornments; oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing trees with precious jeweled branches and stores of incense powders; and oceanic clouds of lion thrones containing adornments of nets festooned with various incenses and jeweled bells as bright as the sun. With these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of immeasurable palaces formed from all manner of wish-fulfilling kings of jewels; oceanic clouds of canopies adorned with all manner of flowers with indranīla anthers; oceanic clouds of canopies with all manner of incenses and gemstones; oceanic clouds of canopies formed like lamps radiating jewel light; oceanic clouds of canopies of kings of jewels resounding with melodies appearing from the Buddha’s magical display; oceanic clouds of canopies that display the appearance of being completely adorned with bejeweled cloth; oceanic clouds of canopies of precious jewels that shine with a blazing flood of flowers; oceanic clouds of canopies of nets of sundry bells that fill everywhere with their sounds; oceanic clouds of canopies of nets of lotus flowers having the essence of gemstones, resplendent with the brightness of infinite variegated blazing lotus flowers; oceanic clouds of canopies of victory banners that shine with the brilliant light rays of golden anthers; and oceanic clouds of canopies bedecked with an inconceivable amount of brilliant, radiant adornments. With these, we will pay homage to all the vast oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic parasols with all manner of various precious jewels; oceanic clouds of parasols of flowers adorned with the ten precious jewels, which radiate brilliant light; oceanic clouds of parasols containing stores of pearls in an infinite variety of colors; oceanic clouds of parasols of the kings of jewels that resound with the teachings on compassion of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas; oceanic clouds of parasols with radiant garlands of various jewels; oceanic clouds of parasols hung with nets of bells completely decorated with brilliant jewel dust; oceanic clouds of parasols adorned with tree branches made from all manner of gemstones; oceanic clouds of parasols with the radiant kings of jewels that shine profusely like the sun and with all manner of incenses and perfumes; oceanic clouds of parasols imbued with stores of sandalwood powder spreading everywhere; and oceanic clouds of parasols imbued with all manner of adornments, filling everywhere and illuminating the vast, great domain of the buddhas. With these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of distinct clouds of maṇḍalas of all manner of brilliant jewels; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of the forms of all manner of radiant jewels; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of brilliant clouds of flowers; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of all manner of radiant jewels emanated by the Buddha; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of light that pervades and illuminates all buddhafields; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of jeweled branches that resound in the buddha realms in all directions; oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of all the light rays emitted by a Mount Meru of beryl, precious substances, and precious jewels; oceanic clouds of light that, in a single instant of thought, fully display all the infinite forms of sentient beings; oceanic clouds of light that produce pleasing sounds arisen from the aspirations of all the buddhas; and oceanic clouds of maṇḍalas of the light of the kings of jewels that possess the melodies that tame all assemblies of sentient beings—with these, we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of oceanic clouds of the light rays of stores of all gemstones; oceanic clouds of light rays of the forms, voices, scents, tastes, and sensations of all the buddhas; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of all precious jewels; oceanic clouds of light rays that fill everywhere with the sounds of the Dharma of all the buddhas; oceanic clouds of light rays that illuminate the entire array of buddhafields; oceanic clouds of the light rays of all multistoried palaces of flowers; oceanic clouds of the light rays of the particles of all jewels; oceanic clouds of light rays possessing the roar of the entire succession of buddhas arising within a single eon, which brings sentient beings to maturation; displays of inexhaustible jewels; oceanic clouds of light rays of the anthers of all flowers; and distinct oceanic clouds of light rays emitted from the array of all thrones. With these we will pay homage to all the oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of distinct oceanic clouds of the infinitely colored radiant light of precious jewels; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of all-illuminating kings of jewels; oceanic clouds of radiant light that illuminates the great, vast array of all buddhafields; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of all manner of incenses; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of all manner of adornments; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of the emanations of all buddhas; oceanic clouds of the radiant light of the anthers of trees of various jewels; and oceanic clouds of the radiant light of all manner of clothes. With these we will pay homage to all the vast oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.

“We will fill the sky with emanations of inconceivable oceanic clouds of the adornments of all manner of various incenses and flowers; oceanic clouds of lotus nets of all manner of radiant jewels; oceanic clouds of stores of pearls endowed with the colors of all manner of jewels; oceanic clouds of powders made from all manner of jewels, incenses, and sandalwoods; oceanic clouds of parasols with all manner of jewels; oceanic clouds possessing pleasing kings of jewels and beautifying melodies; oceanic clouds of garlands with hosts of gemstones possessing the brilliance of the sun; oceanic clouds of infinite stores of jewels; and oceanic clouds of distinct bodies that are perfect in every way. With these, we will pay homage to all the vast oceanic buddhas and bodhisattvas. We will exalt them, honor them, and make offerings to them.”

With such words, they made this aspiration. At this point, all the nāga kings circumambulated the Bhagavān three times and prostrated, touching his feet. With the Bhagavān’s permission, they each took their seats.

At that time, possessing the strength of irreversible aspiration, the lord of all the nāgas in the great trichiliocosm called King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds came to this Jambudvīpa continent in order to listen to the Dharma and make offerings, pay homage, and venerate the Tathāgata. Then, the nāga lord King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds arose from his seat, draped his robe over one shoulder, touched his right knee to the ground with joined palms, and addressed the Bhagavān, asking, “If the Bhagavān can make time to offer an explanation in response to my inquiry, I would ask a question of the bhagavān, tathāgata, foe-destroyer, complete and perfect Buddha.”

The Bhagavān replied to King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds, “Nāga lord, ask whatever you wish, and I will give you an explanation that will delight your mind.”

King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds asked the Bhagavān, “Bhagavān, how can all the nāgas eliminate all the suffering of the nāgas and cause them to attain all manner of happiness and become utterly joyful? How can they cause rain to fall at the proper times here in the continent of Jambudvīpa? How can they cause all manner of grasses, trees, medicinal herbs, and forests to arise? How can they cause all grains to grow? How can they cause all beings to grow? How can they cause all people here in the continent of Jambudvīpa to attain happiness?”

The Bhagavān replied to King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds, “Nāga lord, excellent. It is excellent that you have thought to ask this question of the Tathāgata, in order to benefit all sentient beings and establish them in happiness. Nāga lord, I will explain this to you—listen well and bear my words in mind. Nāga lord, if you possess a single Dharma teaching, you can cause all the nāgas to eliminate all the suffering of the nāgas. What is that single Dharma teaching? It is loving-kindness. Nāga lord, gods and humans who abide in that loving-kindness will not be harmed by fire. They will not be harmed by weapons. They will not be swept away by water. They will not be harmed by poison. They will not be overcome by enemy troops. They will sleep happily and wake happily. They will always preserve their own merit and become brilliant with the splendor of great merit. They will be unconquerable by the entire world with all its gods. They will become beautiful and pleasing to behold. They will be unobstructed on all paths. They will cut off all suffering and become utterly joyful. Having gained all manner of happiness and realized the most unexcelled Dharma among humans, they will take birth in the Brahmā world after their body passes away.

“Nāga lord, these are the benefits for gods and humans who abide in loving-kindness. Therefore, Nāga lord, you should abide with your body, speech, and mind engaged in actions of loving-kindness. Nāga lord, moreover, you should proclaim the dhāraṇī known as bestowing all happiness. In that manner, you will eliminate all the suffering of all the nāgas, bestow all happiness, cause seasonal rain to fall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, and cause all grasses, trees, medicinal herbs, forests, and crops to grow. Nāga lord, how does the dhāraṇī called bestowing all happiness go?

p.mantra: Tadyathā dhāraṇi dhāraṇi uddhāraṇi sampratiṣṭhite vijaya varna satyapratijñāsaradā jñānavati utpadani vināmani abhiśecani abhivyāhāra śubhavati jīmatu ehi kumabālan vaha hara kleśāna dhuna pāvama śodhaya mārgan nirāhikadharmātā śuddhāloka vitimirarājasa dukkha śamana sarva buddha avalokana adhiṣṭhite prajñā jñānabhe svāhā

div.p: “Nāga lord, the words of this dhāraṇī can accomplish all purposes. They involve the Dharma body. They are blessed by all the buddhas. They bestow all manner of happiness. You should uphold and proclaim them. Nāga lord, furthermore, you should uphold and bear in mind the names of the tathāgatas who manifest emanations with the brilliant essence of all the blessings arisen from the family of clouds, who possess the glorious maṇḍala of clouds that rain down a flow of the highest gnosis, and whose lineage and family arise from a single portion of the tip of a hair of golden Vairocana. These names will eliminate all the suffering of the nāgas and fulfill all the provisions of happiness for all nāgas, all nāga families, all nāga lineages, all nāga paternal lines, all nāga elements, all nāga birthplaces, all nāga kings, all nāga daughters, and all nāga servants. What are these names? They are as follows:

“Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Essence of Vairocana. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Completely Beautified with Clouds Producing Nāga Families. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Water-Holding Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Splendor of Glorious Clouds. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Arising. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud That Vanquishes All Maṇḍalas of Wind. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Unfathomable Space. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud’s Host of Blazing Lightning. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Powerful Great Cloud Hero. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Beautiful Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Thick Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Maṇḍala. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud Light.

“Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Lion. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Parasol. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Pleasant Appearance Great Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Filled with Great Clouds. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Resounding of the Drum Tones Pervading All Ten Directions of the Brilliant Maṇḍala Arisen from Clouds. Homage to the tathāgata Great Cooling Cloud’s Deep Roar That Vanquishes Unhappiness. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Expansive Great Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Ganges Water Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Powerful Cloud-Like Hero. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Dragon’s Roar Resounding. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Display of All Clouds. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Expanse.

“Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Dripping Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud-Like Resounding. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud-Like Exaltation. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Wearing Cloud-Like Garments. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud-Born Harvest. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Abiding in the Cloud Abode. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Rain Cloud. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud Gatherer. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Abundant Clouds. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Utpala. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Incense Body. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Exaltation. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Lord. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Illuminator. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Bestowal. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Like a Cloud of Great Precious Jewels. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud-Like Victory.

“Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud River. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Collected Clouds. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Vanquishing Untimely Clouds and Lightning. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud-Like Vision Appearing and Resounding in Space. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Emitting Sound. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Producing Rainfall. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud Fulfilling Equanimity’s Splendor. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Cloud’s Great Water Endowed with Six Flavors. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Cloud Spray. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Great Clouds Filling the Ocean. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Complete Cloud Coverage in Times of Drought. Homage to the bhagavān tathāgata Infinite Cloud Forms. Homage to all the bhagavān, tathāgata, foe-destroyer, complete and perfect buddhas of the great cloud, who possess the brilliance of the cloud that illuminates all the clouds in the continent of Jambudvīpa with glorious, splendid radiance.

“Nāga lord, by proclaiming the names of these tathāgatas, you can eliminate all the suffering of the nāgas, bestow all manner of happiness, cause seasonal rain to fall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, and cause all grasses, trees, medicinal herbs, forests, and crops to grow.”

Then, King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds, lord of the all the nāgas in the great trichiliocosm, addressed the Bhagavān, asking, “Bhagavān, in future times and future seasons when rain is not falling here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, what words can be spoken so that a great rain can be made to fall? I beg you to explain the words of such a secret mantra-dhāraṇī that can utterly pacify all plague, hostility, and harm when one is terrified, when harm arises, when one is drawn into conflict with lawless people, when plague and harm arise, when one is sick or dying, and when the constellations are in inauspicious abodes. I beg you to bless us with the blessings of the Buddha.

“I beg the Bhagavān, with your supreme compassion and concern for the welfare of all sentient beings, to explain the words of such a secret mantra-dhāraṇī that can exhort all the nāgas, bring joy to all the gods, vanquish all māras, destroy all sentient beings’ fears, turn back all harm, produce peace and auspiciousness, pacify the effects of all inauspicious constellations, clear away all five obstacles to rainfall spoken by the Bhagavān, and cause excellent rain to fall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa. Bhagavān, this I beg of you.”

The Bhagavān replied to King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds, “Nāga lord, it is excellent, excellent, that you have asked this question of the Tathāgata for the sake of all sentient beings’ welfare, benefit, and happiness. Nāga lord, in that case, you should listen well and bear my words in mind. There is a dhāraṇī called the crest of heroic majesty endowed with the great roar of thunder that arises from great compassion. For the sake of all sentient beings’ welfare, benefit, and happiness, all the buddhas spoke this dhāraṇī, blessed it, rejoiced in it, and explained it. When there is no rain, it can cause a great rainfall. When there is great rain, it can cause it to stop. It can completely pacify all fatal harm, exhort all the nāgas, please all the gods, vanquish all māras, and bring all manner of happiness to all sentient beings:

p.mantra: Tadyathā mahājñāna avabhāsāni śrītejolakṣmi vṛṣṭivikrama vajra siṁhatane paramavirāja nirmalaguṇa ketusūryaprabhe vimalāṇgayaṣṭi bhara bhara sambhara sambhara dudumbu hana hana mahāprabhe vibhūta mahā maho andhakāre prajñāgraśuddhe paripūrṇṇamaitri maitri viraṇaskandha maitrāmabuddhare jala jala jala jala jalam buddhare bodhyaṅgakusume daśabale caturveśvaradhe aṣṭādaśa apanigabuddhadharme śubhamadi puṇyarāśi śukladharmasamanvite gambhāre virajase vimale viśiṣaprāpte nirāsrapadharme sarvalokajyaiṣṭha jeṣṭhaparapravare anuttare asaṇge dhara dhara dhiri dhiri dhuru dhura śāntamahe śāntavege cara cara cara cara ciri ciri curu curu paramabuddhānumate mahāprajñāpāramite svāhā

q.p: Homage to the tathāgata Vairocana, endowed with oceanic gnosis. Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas. To make a great rain fall here on the continent of Jambudvīpa, I will proclaim the essential mantra of all the nāgas. By the word of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, all five obstacles to rainfall will be cleared away.

p.mantra: Sadyāthedan sara sara siri siri suru suru nāgā nāgā java java jivi jivi juvu juvu

q.p: Great nāgas, come quickly! By the word of the Buddha, send down a great rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa!

p.mantra: Cara cara ciri ciri curu curu

q.p: Great nāgas, come quickly! By the word of the Buddha, send down a great rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa!

p.mantra: Vara vara viri viri vuru vuru

q.p: By the word of the Buddha, all nāgas are summoned. With minds of loving-kindness, compassion, sympathetic joy, and equanimity, through the great blessings, word, and kindness of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, great nāgas, come quickly! Remember the Buddha’s Dharma and the qualities of the bodhisattvas!

p.mantra: Bhara bhara bhiri bhiri bhuru bhuru

q.p: With minds of loving-kindness, all you great wriggling attendants who hold the water of the great rivers and clouds, come quickly! Remember the teacher’s sublime teachings!

p.mantra: Ghaḍa ghaḍa ghiḍi ghiḍi ghuḍu ghuḍu

q.p: With minds of loving-kindness, all you fierce, wrathful, powerful poison-tongued ones, come quickly! By the word of all the tathāgatas, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā!

p.mantra: Taṭa taṭa tiṭi tiṭi tuṭu tuṭu

q.p: All you with your emanated poisonous bodies bearing great jeweled crowns, remember the blessings of the Three Jewels! By the word of Vajrapāṇi, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā!

p.mantra: Kala kala kili kili kulu kulu

q.p: All you who dwell in the great waters and ride mounted on chariots of stacked clouds, come quickly! With minds of loving-kindness, send down a flow of rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa! You are commanded by Vajrapāṇi, by the word and blessings of the Tathāgata!

p.mantra: Rala rala rili rili rulu rulu

q.p: All you slitherers, abandon your sleep, and through the power of the tathāgatas of the three times:

p.mantra: Ghama ghama ghimi ghimi ghumu ghumu svāhā

q.p: All nāgas, you are summoned! With minds of loving-kindness, generating the preliminary mind of awakening:

p.mantra: Nara nara niri niri nuru nuru svāhā

q.p: All you great powerful mahoragas with a thousand different crooked heads, red heads, and red eyes, you are summoned! Hey, hey, you great slitherers, remember the tathāgatas, who possess supreme compassion, blaze with the splendor of all merit, and are free from the afflictions!

p.mantra: Gaṭa gaṭa giṭi giṭi guṭu guṭu svāhā

q.p: All you powerful vanquishers, endowed with unobstructed brilliance, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa!

p.mantra: Śara śara śiri śiri śuru śuru svāhā

q.p: Hey, hey, great nāgas, remember your own families and your paternal lineages, and without delay, through the blessings of the word of all gods, send down flowing rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Through the blessings of the word of Brahmā, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
By the word of Indra, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
By the word of the Four Great Kings, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the eight ones, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the stream enterers, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the once-returners, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the non-returners, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the worthy ones, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of the pratyekabuddhas, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word of all the buddhas and bodhisattvas, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
Great nāgas, by the word and blessings of all the tathāgatas, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
By the word of all gods, pacify all harm, svāhā.
By the word of all nāgas, send rainfall down here to the great earth, svāhā.
By the word of all yakṣas, protect all sentient beings, svāhā.
By the word of all gandharvas, remove all conflict and harm among people, svāhā.
By the word of all asuras, turn back all malignant constellations, svāhā.
By the word of all garuḍas, make all the nāgas act with loving-kindness and send down a great flow of rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.
By the word of all kinnaras, pacify all evil and satisfy all sentient beings, svāhā.
By the word of all mahoragas, send down a broad and vast flow of rainfall and seize the five hindrances to rainfall, svāhā.
By the word of all humans, completely protect all people, svāhā.

p.mantra: Kara kara kiri kiri kuru kuru dara dara diri diri duru duru naṭa naṭa niṭi niṭi nuṭu nuṭu

q.p: Lady Swift Departure, Lady Bearer of Great Clouds’ Water, Lady Cloud, Lady Great Cloud, Lady Great Cloud Water Bearer, Lady Bright Cloud, Lady Cloud Born, Lady Seasonal Cloud, Lady Cloud Source, Lady Cloud Roar, Lady Cloud Dweller, Lady Cloud Crown, Lady Cloud Garland Wearer, Lady Adorned by Clouds, Lady Cloud Mount, Lady Cloud Home, Cloud Essence, Cloud Locks, Lady Cloud Light, Lady Cloud Retinue, Lady Abides in Vast Clouds, Lady Holding Cloud Offerings, Lady Bringing Harvest, Lady Mountain Dweller, Nāga Mother Bhagavatī, Great Cloud Glorious Star Colored, Lady Cool, Lady Domain of Great Comprehension, Lady Who Manifests the Great Nāgas, Bhagavatī, Lady Who Holds the Six Extracted Essences—by the word of the Buddha, please send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.

p.mantra: Ghara ghara ghiri ghiri ghuru ghuru ghirini ghirini ghuma ghuma ghuma ghuma ghuma ghuma ghuma ghuma ghumari

q.p: Lady Nine Heads, Lady Great Cloud Garland, Lady Lightning Garland, Lady Holder of All Slitherers, Lady Wearing Cloud-Like Raiment, Lady Domain of All Fierce Poisons, Lady Mounted on Arrayed Clouds, Lady Dragon’s Roar, Lady Roar, Lady Nāga Inciter, Goddess Great Cloud Garland—exhort all the nāgas, saying, ‘Without delay, through the blessings of the Tathāgata, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa,’ svāhā.

Buddhe buddhe bubuddhe subuddhe hara pāpana sarva satvānān adhiṣṭhayapuṇyama sarva buddhanān dharini dhare śubhamate guṇāgraprāpane mahājñānolake śukladharme sadyapratijñā mahāyānādhyuṣite lokajyeṣṭhabhagavati buddhamaitreyayuvuraya sarva kṣetrāni śukleśvetvama paradāre panaṭaravasini dhudhure dhudhuru śama śama śāntamānase

q.p: May you completely clear away all hindrances to rainfall, svāhā.
By the word of all the tathāgatas of the three times, who engage in perfect conduct with minds of loving-kindness and possess flawless minds of austerity, we exhort all the great nāgas.
Great nāga king King Parasol-Like Splendid Maṇḍala of the Array of All-Covering Oceanic Clouds, we exhort you—send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.

These and all other nāga kings, we exhort you—send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.

p.mantra: Nāge nāge mahānāge ghoramānase nāgahṛdaya dhuma kule ugraroṣe pracaṇḍatejo viṣogre āśāviśe atighore kṛṣṇapiṇgale canacale lolajihve mahāphanakare kālapāśe raudravāsani ṭuṭumāve ghaṇa ghaṇa śikhini kaṇa kaṇa gaṇa gaṇa mahāgaṇagaṇe para para piri piri puru puru visphurjane bhuru bhuru mahābhoge maṇidhari phiri phiri phuru phuru phara phara varṣa varṣa jalāmbudhare ṣambu ṣambu vataḍutampe dhud dhud dhud dhumve meghaprabhe meghavātine ḍhaka ḍhaka ḍhaka ḍhu ḍhumve ghaṇā ghaṇā śikini kana kana gaṇa gaṇa mahānāgagane nirātraṇya vajra dakāri mahānāgādhivataye ghuma ghuma ghuma payāstika jāṅgārighujaṃśame pikatasaṅkate ghoravisphurjani vijṛmabhante

q.p: All nāgas, you are summoned. Through the blessings of all buddhas and the word and minds of loving-kindness of all the tathāgatas of the three times, send down rainfall here in the continent of Jambudvīpa, svāhā.

div.p: Namaḥ sarva buddhebhyaḥ siddhantu mantrapadāni svāhā”
div.trailer: From the hundred thousand chapters of the noble “Great Cloud Discourse,” this is the sixty-fourth chapter, entitled “The Maṇḍala of Wind That Sends Down Rainfall.”

div.head: Ritual Procedure
div.p: One who desires to produce a great rainfall should first go to an open, clean area and erect a blue canopy, decorating it with blue pennants. The Dharma practitioner should bathe their body, abide by the eightfold precepts, and don clean blue garments. Having anointed themself with pleasant-smelling incense, they should consume the three white foods and seat themself upon a blue cushion, facing east. After supplicating all the tathāgatas, they should read aloud this chapter on the great cloud maṇḍala, day and night without interruption.

They should set out four vases filled with blue water, together with as much offering cakes, incense, and flowers as they can gather. The Dharma practitioner should then use liquified cow dung to draw figures in the four directions. In the eastern direction they should use cow dung to draw a three-headed nāga king, three cubits tall, with a retinue of various nāga attendants. In the southern direction they should draw a five-headed nāga king, five cubits tall, with a retinue of various nāga attendants. In the western direction they should draw a seven-headed nāga king, seven cubits tall, with a retinue of various nāga attendants. In the northern direction they should draw a nine-headed nāga king, nine cubits tall, with a retinue of various nāga attendants. The Dharma practitioner should guard their own body, abiding in loving-kindness, and establish an attitude of compassion toward all sentient beings. Then, they should supplicate all the buddhas and bodhisattvas and share the virtuous roots with the nāgas. This is the ritual procedure.

If one reads aloud this chapter on the great cloud maṇḍala of wind during a time of drought, then within one full day, two full days, or up to seven full days, it is certain that rain will fall. The ocean may recede with the tides, but this ritual for bringing rainfall, the speech of the Great Sage, will never change. That being the case, however, one must abide in discipline and virtuous qualities and abandon lax discipline, meat, fish, and the like. One should consume rice gruel, curds, milk, rice with sugar, the three sweets, and so forth. In this fashion, the ritual will be successful. As this was spoken by the King of Sages, there should be no doubts about this.
div.trailer: From the noble Great Vehicle discourse called “Great Cloud,” this is the sixty-fourth chapter entitled “The Maṇḍala of Wind That Sends Down Rainfall,” together with its ritual manual.

div.head: Colophon
div.p: Translated, revised, and finalized according to the new terminology by the Indian preceptors Jinamitra and Śīlendrabodhi and the great editor-translator Bandé Yeshé Dé.

gloss.term: A being who has produced the intent to achieve full awakening for the benefit of sentient beings.
A “solitary buddha” who pursues nirvāṇa on their own, without a teacher.
Fourth of the four fruits. An individual who has achieved liberation with the cessation of all mental afflictions. Also used as an epithet of a buddha.
Defiled mental or emotional states that disturb the mind. Said to number eighty-four thousand.
Upholding ethical conduct of body, speech, and mind. Second of the six or ten perfections.
Direct knowledge of emptiness and ultimate reality.
Long-lived celestial beings. One of the six classes of beings.
A class of nonhuman bird-like beings.

A class of semidivine beings who inhabit forests, mountainous areas, and other natural spaces, or serve as guardians of villages and towns, and may be propitiated for health, wealth, protection, and other boons. They are often depicted as holding choppers, cleavers, and swords, and are said to dwell in the north, under the jurisdiction of the Great King Vaiśravaṇa.
A class of nonhuman beings known particularly for their musical abilities.
A class of nonhuman horse-like beings.
A class or powerful nonhuman beings, sometimes called demigods, who are often portrayed as the enemies of the devas. One of the six classes of beings.
A class of nonhuman snake-like beings.
A type of incantation. Also used to refer to the mental capacity to retain teachings that one has heard, and to mnemonic devices used to aid such retention.
The Buddha as the embodiment of his teachings, the all-encompassing aspect of absolute reality.
stong gsum gyi stong chen po’i ’jig rten gyi khams
The largest measure of the universe as composed of a billion smaller world-systems.
One who has entered the stream that leads to liberation. The first of the four fruitions.
One who is bound for only one further rebirth. Second of the four fruitions.
One who will not be reborn again. Third of the four fruitions.
Eight precepts observed by householders, particularly around certain ritual observances.
Three foods that are suitable for offering: milk, curd, and rice.
One of the celestial realms belonging to the form realm, it is ruled over by the god Brahmā.
An array of people or things, often referring to an arrangement of buddhas and bodhisattvas together with their celestial retinues.
The most supreme of jewels, typically used as an epithet for diamonds.
A world that has been transformed and blessed by a buddha. Similar to a “buddha realm.”
A world that has been transformed and blessed by a buddha. Similar to a “buddhafield.”
A type of jewel associated with the god Indra, likely referring to a sapphire.

An epithet of a buddha. Muni is an ancient title, derived from the verb man (“to contemplate”), given to someone who has attained the realization of a truth through their own contemplation and not by divine revelation.
Ten precious substances. According to one list, in a Chinese commentary to the Buddhāvataṃsaka, these are: gold, silver, beryl, cat’s eye, emerald, coral, amber, pearl, carnelian, and sodalite.
The deities ruled over by Māra, the adversary of the Buddha and the personification of everything that hinders awakening.
char pa'i bar chad byed pa lnga

Five conditions that prevent timely rainfall. In a discourse in Chinese translation, the Discourse on the Arising of Worlds (Qishi jing 起世經, T. 24, 1:349b1-c14), these are given as: (1) The asura king Rāhula emerges from his palace, gathers the rain clouds in both hands, and hurls them into the ocean; (2) The power of the fire element increases, causing the rain clouds to dissipate; (3) The power of the wind element increases, blowing the rain clouds into the desert or the wilderness; (4) The spirits responsible for causing rainfall become derelict in their duties, and thus the rain clouds dissipate without releasing rain; (5) The majority of people in Jambudvīpa become mired in affliction and desire and engage in unethical conduct, so the heavens refuse to send down rain.
rnam par snang bar byed pa

An epithet of the Buddha Śākyamuni. Muni is an ancient title, derived from the verb man (“to contemplate”), given to someone who has attained the realization of a truth through their own contemplation and not by divine revelation.
A bodhisattva known for his excellent conduct and his vow to make limitless offerings to all buddhas.
A bodhisattva known as a fierce protector of the Buddha.
